This probably will get berried, but in these threads the whole talking to strangers thing usually gets brought up and as an american this is true, but there are some things i'm not sure you all realize about it.
First, this stranger conversation is very closely tied with the other theme of Americans being "superficial." These conversations on the outside appear as if two people are becoming new friends, but that very rarely is the case. We mostly keep the conversation as light hearted as possible.
Also this might be a generational thing for younger people (im 23) but I feel like there are a lot of invitations that people extend to new friends that are truly only half genuine. I think we just have an idea of sensing when they are genuine and when they aren't. I think with American youth people extend invitations to new acquaintances that are more so to be polite then an actual reflection of how you feel about them.
I haven't spent substantial time outside of the US so who knows, but I sense this point isn't always emphasized.
